title: How has the percentage of smokers quitting changed?
analysis_commentary:
Though smoking prevalence has fallen in the last decade, the health consequences of smoking present a major health challenge. The success of Smoking Cessation services is judged by the number of people who quit smoking within a certain time period - often called the quit rate.

The highest proportion of quitters was seen in 2003/04, when 57% of people who set a quit date quit smoking within four weeks. In 2003/04, the Department of Health's first integrated smoking campaign launched, which included the first campaigns designed to be highly emotional, which may have been responsible (http://smokefree.nhs.uk/resources/campaign/). Since then, the proportion of quitters has steadily declined to the lowest level of 49% in 2010/11. However in the past two years, the published data suggest that the proportion of quitters has been increasing recently and was 52% in 2012/13.
data_source: Health & Social Care Information Centre, Statistics on NHS Stop Smoking Services in England
